title: China Relief Rally Can Only Go So Far; Covid restrictions to remain onerous for some time, and there remain many other issues to spook investors in China
text:
Neither are yet reality, but hopes of both are enough to drive stocks higher. "Buy the rumor," as an old investment adage goes. Lower-than-expected U.S. inflation had already sent Chinese stocks up Friday, but they surged further when news of China's easing its quarantine requirements broke in the afternoon. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, or HSCEI, surged 8.3% while both Alibaba and Tencent gained 12%.

Apart from easing quarantine requirements, Beijing also relaxed somewhat a number of other pandemic restrictions, such as narrowing the scope of close contacts subject to isolation. None of those, however, would mean a meaningful reopening in the near future.

Visitors to China would still need to quarantine for eight days, with five of those in a hotel. More disruptive policies such as frequent lockdowns also seem to stay for a while. Many areas in China's southern metropolis of Guangzhou are currently in lockdown as Covid cases have surged. Meanwhile, Apple said Sunday shipments of its new iPhones will be lower due to pandemic restrictions at factories assembling its products nearly a thousand miles north in Zhengzhou.

An eventual reopening is at least months away. The elderly vaccination rate is still relatively low, and cases will likely surge during the colder months. And the government will need to dial down its tough rhetoric on the pandemic first.

Markets nonetheless are excited because they believe Beijing is preparing for life after its zero-Covid rules, even if it is progressing slowly. Investors also seem more willing to take on risks with the hope of a Fed pivot.

Prospects for a continued rebound in the near term are helped by the fact that Chinese stocks have been sold down heavily. Even after Friday's rally, the HSCEI has lost 29% this year, underperforming the S&P 500's 17% decline. While the latter is still above its level at the end of 2020, Chinese stocks have almost halved since then. The HSCEI trades at 7.6 times forward earnings, according to FactSet, compared with average 11.6 times over the past five years.

The zero-Covid policy was only one reason why Chinese stocks have fallen so much. China's property marketremains in the doldrums. The crackdown on various private-sector industries, particularly technology, has also got investors worried about the direction the economy is heading.

An eventual pivot from zero Covid doesn't mean zero worries for investors in China.

Write to Jacky Wong at jacky.wong@wsj.com
